chapter.title: Observation Practice
chapter.content:
In this unit you will practice making specific, objective observations for principles of learning. We highly recommend that you develop your skills in this type of observation using the same video provided in Unit 1, although this time viewing the entire 30-minute video. This will allow you to use a new observation protocol featured in Unit 2 and also to benefit from comparing your observation notes with those of seasoned adult educators who viewed the same video.

However, if you do not teach ESL learners and would prefer viewing videos of other classes, you have the option to select an alternative video (see the Suggested Alternatives page for suggestions).

 

 

Return to main course page.

chapter.title: Using an Observation Protocol
chapter.content:
Many teachers have limited experience observing other classes besides their own. Frequently, observers confuse observation with evaluation, or they focus only on what the teacher does rather than also noting the activities, interactions, and behaviors of the students. In this course, you will practice doing observations that objectively describe what teachers and students are doing during instruction. Then you will consider what your observations tell you about the teacher's use of the principles of learning for instructional design.

To practice, you will observe the ESL lesson you already viewed on video, now focusing on careful description of what you see. The observation tool you use should be focused on the instructional practices you selected as needing more support in (in the self-assessment, ones you rated 1 or 2. Instructional Design Stategies Self-Assessment Tool [Word]). This may require that you adapt an available observation tool by selecting a small subset of items so that the observer can stay focused on the target practices; the example shown here demonstrates how this protocol can be focused more narrowly on four instructional design strategies.

Let's return to view the ESL class that you watched in Unit 1 and this time watch the entire 30-minute video, using the Observation Protocol to guide your focus.

  • Before you view the video again, download and print out a copy of the Observation Protocol (Word).

chapter.title: Post-Observation Questions
chapter.content:
After viewing the lesson with the Observation Protocol, consider the questions that follow. If you opted to watch a different video than the one  provided in the course, please identify which video you watched and its Web site, before answering the question.

  1. What is one “specific, concrete, and descriptive” observation you would share with Andrea, the teacher in the videotaped class? (Share your remarks in the course thread in the LINCS Evidence-Based Professional Development Community of Practice and discover what previous course participants observed.)

  2. One former course participant noted the following about her own experience as an observer:
    What I found most difficult in taking notes during the observation was describing what I was seeing and omitting evaluative language. This was the biggest challenge because I had so many suggestions in mind while I was observing. I concentrated on what the students were doing and what the teacher was doing. That helped me to describe what I saw.

    What was challenging for you about doing the observation? (Share your remarks in the course thread in the LINCS Evidence-Based Professional Development Community of Practice and discover what other course participants found challenging).

chapter.title: Compare Observation Notes
chapter.content:
What observers consider worth noting during an observation can have a large impact on what the observed teacher then pays attention to.

  • Read this set of Observation Notes (Word) to see what another educator noticed in Andrea’s class.

  • Compare what each of you noticed and consider how your discussions with teacher Andrea would be similar or different, based on what you focused on.
